reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very good WW1 simulator which utilizes trench warfare to almost perfection. Camping and tactical play play a major part in this game from a defensive perspective but when attacking you need to carefully plan your attacks and attack where the enemy is weak. Infiltrating an enemy trench and stealthily killing everyone there can never get boring with the added suspension of not knowing what is behind the next trench corner. The game rewards you working as a squad with the spawn mechanic where if the leader of the squad is deep behind enemy lines the squad players can spawn on him and help with the capturing of the trench. The game also has a one shot kill mechanic for rifles where the best marksman will be the one to get the kill to add further suspense. The developers have also added massive amount of historical accuracy in the gun designs ;  the outfits of the soldiers also look amazing.

Well worth the buy for its price and the game has still got more to come from it when the official release comes.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
holy ♥♥♥♥. this game is amazing..

i'm big into world war one. There's really not a lot of world war one games worth a damn on steam and besides this one they're all strategy pretty much. Verdun is a world war one game more then anything else. Muddy trenches, muddy nomansland, muddy everything. Artillery shells falling, gas floating into your shellhole, Rifles crack from all over, the occasional sound of a lewis gun firing rattles in your ears. The atmosphere is amazing, although sometimes maps are lacking players. There are several maps, each based on a different section of line on the western front. From Flanders, the muddy, stalemate of a map, to the Aisne, a rather unscathed piece of battlefield with trees growing and pretty foliage (lots of hiding spots). The mechanics are great (with the exception of one) and amazing for a world war one game. THIS IS NOT A GENERIC SHOOTER. The ballistics are probably unlike anything you've seen, and the change from assault rifles to your bolt action enfields and lebels is an awesome change of pace in a game. The game focuses on attack and defend gameplay, and can sometimes result in very trench warfare-esque stalemates. There's a time limit to prevent too much of a boring stalemate though. You can level up and unlock new weapons for your classes, and pick from one of several squads from each side, such as Poilus, Landsers, Tommies, Alpenjager, etc.
If you play with the same squad members a few times you will earn squad xp earning you bonuses like better artillery, more points, and late war uniforms. The graphics are also amazing, especially for an indie game. THE ONE FLAW I have with this game is the melee. I think its pretty lacking for a world war one game where hand to hand combat was the norm. But this is a minor flaw, I just hope it gets improved down the road.

And on that note my final praise. The devs started working on this sometime around 2006-7? And they finished the thing this long after? Thats a crazy feat for indie developers, and they have showed they will provide regular updates that are very good unlike many early access developers. That's all good, but even after the game has been released they have just now unveiled their plans for after the games release. A BUNCH of huge updates, FREE! Adding things like night maps, US squads, flamethrowers, gore, and more!

AMAZING game!

reviewText: Verdun is based in the tumultuous and incredibly bloody World War I, where trench warfare and the rise of the first tanks took place. The game takes you to various locals and humongous maps spanning the length of France. I have long been an admirer of history, and I must say that this game has not disappointed me in keeping to the period.\nTo speak of the graphics, the game in it's earliest form was basic at the least. However, it has gone far from those nascent graphics and has blossomed into a grimy and bloody masterpiece of historical-based games. Gun models are very realistic and detailed, and include things such as serial numbers and maker's etchings for those that look closer than just the far sights. Uniforms, with the benefit of a scrupulous historical adviser and modeling team, are top notch and pleasant to the eye, as much as they are to the period. On top of these, much work has been done to detail every inch of maps with props and trenches that are again as if they were lifted right from the annals of time to be played by our more recent generation.\nGame play is formed to follow the manner of tactics used at the time, with the defending or assaulting of trenches, where the capturing of a trench by your team earns it one grueling, hard-won point. After such a minor victory has been achieved, you must then aid your team in defending your well-earned prize for a time before continuing on to the next trench or, failing that, being beaten back to start anew. In this, Verdun captures the essence of the period brutally, but beautifully. You are also able to have a variety of characters at your command that are chosen from a squad." A squad

For instance, each squad has a leader that can call down powerful artillery, noxious gas, or recon planes to give the location of enemies to you and your entire team. Or you can have machine gunners that lay down anything within their field of fire. More squad types are on the way according to the Verdun wiki, which should be very interesting in future gameplay, especially if they also were to include the Russian faction as well, though such a squad might have some internal dissention...\nIn any case, with the exception of a few player-based hiccups, there is little that can be said against the game, besides the occasional problems for people to connect to friends at times, which could be a rather essential bug were it not to be addressed. I recommend yes for those that are looking into this game, as it is educational and fun for all that would play as a soldier of the muddy, frightening, maddening, grueling, and wonderful Verdun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I quite fancy this game. Haven't played it all that much but with the 3 or so hours i've put in thus far i'm liking it. Many of the maps look fantastic (Playing on highest settings), except the Flanders map which looks like a giant turd. The gameplay is nice, quite like Red Orchestra 2 but with less automatic weapons and more trenches. There is unit variety and each role has a unique feature.

Overall, if you have a decent PC and have enjoyed other historical shooters (like Red Orchestra) then you are sure to enjoy this one. Also, it's only in BETA stages, so it can presumably only get better from here.

reviewText: Verdun is a tactical WW1 FPS with an emphasis on teamwork revolving around 4 man squads. The gameplay and visual style of the game is similiar to Red Orchestra 2\Rising Storm, although there are several unique elements involving trench based combat and some unorthodox class loadouts (get used to using handguns and revolvers, which are quite handy in some circumstances). Getting your head around these unique elements might take a few hours and you'll probably die a lot, much like the real inexperienced soldiers of WW1, but after gaining a bit of experience Verdun is a very exciting and rewarding gaming experience.\n\nHighly Recommended unless you suck at games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although the game is still in Early Access(beta) and one of the pioneer World War I First Person Shooters, the game shown great promise and and interesting gameplay.

You can use Defensive Squads or Assault Squads, each slot with a special unit with unique abilities and items. You can give orders as a NCO (Squad Leader), or follow your NCO with any other class such as Rifleman, Sniper or even Grenadier.

You can also customize your squad with different helmets, uniforms, and badges. And also you can name your own squad! (NOTE: This game have level system on it. You can level up your soldier AND your squad. In Order to customize your squad you MUST get some squad level)

The Graphics are quite amazing and if you don't own a beefy" Gaming PC the game will run properly too!(Just set the graphics to low quality) Though I suggest having a good internet connection while playing it
date:
since it is an FPS and it requires a bit of a stable connection.

Some of the physics are good but falls short a little bit and sometimes(Such as Grenades Physics) internet lag or even FPS drop can happen. Though it's a Early Access and the Developers promised fixing these kind of issues(The developers work really hard on this game and keep it up to date everytime they can).

Such as in Real Life all the nations have different equipments and weapons. Each one with unique traits

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTo stand out amidst a sea of generic shooters takes a bit of work. Fortunately, Verdun stands out by virtue of the setting - World War I. Despite being almost ideal for translation into gaming, Verdun is the first FPS to really put a player in first-person WWI combat. The attack/defend system is ideal for the core gameplay, and the different abilities within a squad is a nice take on a familiar mechanic. The small dev team is evident as soon you start the game, but really the appeal of Verdun is that it takes place in an oft-overlooked period of history. By that fact, the sort of player that is attracted to this game is also the sort of player who can look past a lack of polish and just enjoy what is a very rare, and very fun gaming experience. Immer weiter Kameraden.

reviewText:
Poke your head out of a trench. BAM HEADSHOT
Respawn. You run out of your trench and make it into a crater left by artillery. Hiding from enemy Lewis gun fire you continue to dodge and weave from crater to crater, ditch to ditch. GASSEN! Its time to put your mask on as you push into the enemy trench.

The artillery strike left by your commander has ravaged the enemy. Through the gas you can see the bodies of fallen enemies. You must push on through the carnage. You turn a corner and *BOOM * a grenade goes off at your feet. As you wait for respawn you cant help but feel a little anger, a little frustration, and a determination to never fight a war like this again

10/10 Would become Uncle Adolf and try to stop brother wars again.

Early Access Review

FInally, a WWI shooter...

Lots of fun!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA few days prior to seeing Verdun on the Holiday Sale, my friends and I were discussing the lack of any WWI shooters available on the market. When I saw this game on the Steam listing, it was like seeing our discussion come to life. With the historical aspects of the Great War as well as the cooperative aspects one looks for in a multiplayer game, Verdun has reached every expection I set when discussion the hypothetical" WWI shooter. The squad system allows for extremely balanced gameplay in addition to promoting teamwork. Furthermore
date: the in-game mechanics revolving around trench warfare allow for a sort of "flow" no present in most multiplayer games. Overall
recommended: grab a few friends (3+ for maximum efficiency) and have fun travelling back about 100 years to fight alongside others in one of the best multiplayer games I've played in a long time."

Put yer iPad Lytes down and listen up, kids. This game is in Early Access (at the time of writing) and has already managed to impress me by doing WW1 FPS well. I ran into very few bugs. It handles well and is fun IF you're prepared to communicate and work as a team. The graphics are good, but once again the game is not finished and not an AAA movie-budget game. Besides, the graphics should not put you off Verdun at all. The price might put you off, but it's worth it even at this stage.

In short, it's good. If you're a Red Orchestra 2 fan, then chances are you'll like this.

reviewText: Seems like lately their patches have broken the game more than fixed it. Heavy FPS drops, join bugs that require you to try rejoin or exit out the game completely to get it to work, bad hitboxes, invisible objects at a distance. It's a mess. The melee system is also atrocious, that uses a sort of auto aim system which simply turns into who ever clicks first or the fastest wins. There are melee specific classes and the best method of actually using that weapon is if you lay prone around a corner and wait to hit someone in the cankles to kill them.\n\nAlso there's no friendly fire on. Meaning there's no need to be careful to rain massive amounts of artillery on your own squad to shield them from the enemy, or care for where you spam grenade and machine gun fire.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVerdun is something fresh in the FPS market. While there are AAA titles like Battlefield and COD going on, all set with their ACOG sights and HOLO sights and Ergo grips and other tacticool crap on their automatic weapons, there is Verdun. Verdun is a game set in the First World War, also known as the Great War. There aren't any fancy sights, or getting a mag emptied on somebody and not killing them, or airstrikes and tanks. Instead, there are bolt actions, early machine guns, and semi-automatic pistols. Even though this game is in Early Access, and has some bugs here and there, this game is a blast and has a lot of potential in future updates. In addition, the group of three devs have done more work on this game than some entire companies do on their game, and it shows in the quality.  If you want to finally play a game that is in WWI and authentic, then get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not only the greatest WW1 FPS ever made (yes, I'm aware the list is short), but it is also a fantastic attack/defend squad-based shooter.

While still in beta (getting better with every update), the gameplay is beautiful. Nothing feels more rewarding than getting a lung-shot (1 hit kill with those) from over 200 meters away all while accounting for bullet drop and velocity (lead your target!).

There are very minor graphical glitches than can occur, but overall it looks and feels fantastic.

If this is how good it is pre-release, it's going to be one hell of an addictive shooter once fully completed and polished.

A must buy for anyone who enjoys squad-based shooters and wishes to experience a sense of nostalgia no other game out can produce.

Get it and enjoy the feelings of victory, frustration, excitement, surprise, and thrill of the kill all at once.

A definite buy!

reviewText: First and foremost: You are going to die.\n\nThere is no point in trying to deny that in this game. You will be shot at, blown to bits, stabbed, hacked at, cut down by wire, mauled by a blunt weapon or cut open with a trench spade. This game is brutal. You will feel some kind of shell shock when french 75ers rain down on you and your squad. You will grasp quickly for that 4" button when gas comes up. You will hate yourself for not reloading properly and having no round in the chamber in a pitched situation. This game is gloomy
date: dark and unforgiving. The maps are brilliantly orchestrated to only allow a few tactics that almost always end with hundreds of deaths by you and your teammates. I've seen pros complaining and yelling about the unfairness of the game. Men and women with hundreds of hours on their record. If you get hit by a bullet
recommended: you'll most likely die. One hit
hoursPlayed:
one death. No mercy.

So why do I do this?

Because it's supposed to be like that! WW1 is everything but a nice place. This game gives you a glimpse into that dark
voteText:
unforgiving time. Into the trenches and back out again.

But is it fun?

Oh yes! Tactics are limited
helpfulPercent: but must be performed in great accuracy. You can  outmaneuver the enemy if you play it right. You can be the hero of your squad or team by being the first in the enemy trench

it's your squad and your team that you have to rely on. They as a whole decide if they attack or if the are dead. This is no game for people to sit in their favorite spot. This is a game in which you have to attack. Or you'll die.

Oh … and die you will.

reviewText:
I've been playing Verdun since shortly after it appeared as an Early Access game on Steam, and while I have written a review for this game before, I decided that with the game being fully released, I should update it.

Verdun is a squad based World War I shooter. There are four members to a squad and four squads per side (Germany and the Entente (currently the game only focuses on the Western Front.) Both sides take turns attacking and defending their trenches, and the side the takes the most ground will win.

Throughout my time playing this game, I have seen many complaints about the difficulty of this game and how they are nothing but cannon fodder for experienced players. Unfortunately, the game does not have level based matchmaking (it would be impossible with the player counts as they are,) and so as a new player you will face off against veteran players. But, while initially this could be very difficult for new players to handle, most players are using the same (or similar) weapons, and once you learn how to use those weapons, you will be at an level playing field with veterans.

This game has glitches and other stability issues, but overall is a beauty. You will die, a lot, but that is to be expected from a game about the trenches of the Great War. I would recommend giving Verdun a shot (pun intended) as it is a unique FPS experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in beta and needs help.  If you've ever wanted a Great War FPS then this game needs your support.  It has a lot of potential, but needs a lot of work.
The attack and defend system in this game is perfect for the back and forth battle for the trenches. I am excited for more content.
If you have a lot of patience with the fledgling player community and a very buggy beta, I think you can find a lot to enjoy in this game.
July 29 Edit:
There has been a lot of hard work done on this game.  As an added bonus, it's on sale for 33 per cent off!  It costs less than seven dollars and a huge influx of players have arrived.
That said, the game gets progressively better and better with each update.  There are nicer visual models, smoother gameplay, and constant bug fixes.  With more players, it has a better feel of the great war.  I highly, highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game is by far one of the most imersive FPS shooters out there.  Put on a pair of headphones, and within five minutes, you will feel yourself actually ducking from bullets and artillery.  The gameplay works well, albeit it may take a while to get used to the specifics.  The only complaint I have so far is I didn't quite grasp how to actually get an MG playing as the Gunner class when I first started.  You have to select it and spend a point whilst in a match to unlock it.  Some may consider it a waste of a point, but considering most classes, with their upgrades are simply to a different rifle, there isnt much else to spend it on.  Add in that you get quite a good ammount at the start and each time you level up, you'll have the wepons to match your style in no time.

Can't wait for the future updates!

Currently, 9/10.

reviewText:
This is an amazing game.

Verdun is a squad based multiplayer first person shooter set in the first world war. It's name is the giveaway for the developers inspiration.
The game is historically accurate and is very realistic. The premise is simple, attack and defend - but you will find yourself crawling through trenches with your gasmask on praying that the next artillery strike does not end your life before you can take the enemy trench or hold your own.

There is an interesting array of skills and weaponary available to you via an unlocking process not dissimilar to BF3/4 - there is a ranking system also.

If you like first person shooters and/or you have in interest in world war one - you must own this game. The developers continually update it, and for Austalians like me there is an AU server and it's active.

enjoy!

reviewText:
Verdun, though not yet fully released, is a WW1 fps which offers satisfying and challenging gameplay individually and as a squad member. Tactics reflect Western Front reality - frontal assaults - so some may find that limiting. The devs are doing a good job of refining an already solid game.

If you like RO2, there are similarities which would merit your taking a look at Verdun.

THE GAME HAS BEEN RELEASED A LONG TIME NOW. The graphics and performance has greatly improved making it much more satisfying to play. There are now some highly experienced and competernt players who know every inch of the maps. Consequently, this game can only be described as hardcore"
date:
newcomers especially will have to invest a good amount of time and effort to become familiar with the game.

Squadplay is rewarding and frustrating in equal measures at times. Deathmatch is satsisfying especially when there is a fair balance between rambos and campers to mix things up!

Verdun is the best WW1 fps available; you will die a helluva lot before you become the scalp-taker everyone falls to!  :)

Highly recommended especially if you like investing time to develop the skills required by the game!"

reviewText: This game perfectly captures the various aspects of World War I in a manner that is both realistic and fun.  The graphics, while not the best, are quite good for an indie game, and while the UI might not look impressive, it does its job well.  All the different classes and weapons are very well balanced against one another, and the maps offer as much variety in scenery and gameplay as is possible given its setting.  It's gameplay mechanics recreate the back and forth of trench warfare in a manner that doesn't feel forced, and gameplay offers a stark contrast in engagements, either sniping across no-man's-land, where machine guns and rifles dominate, or the savage close quarters trench combat in which pistols and grenades excel.  The only real problem the game suffers from is optimization issues, with lower framerates and higher ping that is to be expected.  However, the developers have done quite a bit to fix this issue, reducing its severity and scope to the point of a minor, occasional annoyance.  In my opinion, this is probably the best shooter obtainable for $20 on Steam, and is well worth its asking price.  I wholeheartedly recommend this game, but feel free to look at more recent gameplay videos to assess its character, and make sure to read the Official Steam Guide to ensure that you understand some of its less-explained mechanics.

reviewText:
Verdun is not like other World War Shooters, because Verdun is actually like a World War. In this case, WWI. That means instead of running around with a silly knife performing ridiculous acrobatic feats and stabbing enemies to death, or wading into battle with an improbably configured, heavily accessorized gun, you'll be crawling across a shattered, shell-pocked wasteland for minutes on end without seeing the enemy, only to get blown up by a lucky mortar shell or find yourself spotted and taken out by a machine gunner. Because that's how WWI was. You'll use the actual weapons fighting men were issued, and their lethality will be accurate— one good hit from a rifle round and you're done. Because that's how WWI was. You'll force a bloody foothold and eventually sweep an enemy trench clean, only to have to defend it from counterattack moments later to hold the few meters you've taken. Because that's how WWI was.

For a relatively little-known shooter, Verdun is impressive— the take-and-hold dynamic of its gameplay is unique and challenging, rewarding lots of different skills and battlefield roles from combat to command. The environments are well designed and evocative, there's period-accurate gear, squads, and dialog. Gameplay is fun and fluid. Teamwork garners great rewards; a single good officer can effectively win a game if the enemy team doesn't have coordination to match and he's got a cooperative squad under him.

In terms of cons: the squad level up dynamic can be a bit inaccessible and those who figure it out tend to have a strong advantage, but it doesn't tip the game too badly. Team coordination sadly lacks, possibly weighed down by the somewhat dated automated dialog system of pressing a series of numbers to autotype important phrases; teamwork might be easier if there were a better way to mark up the map, but any HUD elements or radar" components would also hurt the organic feel of the game
date: so it's a bit of being stuck between a rock and a hard place from a dev's perspective
recommended: I reckon. I find that the trenches don't end up being used as heavily as one might think; I wonder if this has to do with the way the game is designed or the limitations of scale that online gameplay imposes. The only true complaint I have about Verdun is that I want it to be so much more; if you've ever read Sniping in France you know the crucial roles that intelligence gathering

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor so long I had longed for a WWI shooter, and felt resigned to the fact that it would never happen because it was simply too difficult a setting to translate into a compelling video game. Then Verdun was released and changed everything. This $17 game is worth more than the last three $60 COD games.  It has a totally unique squad based system which can allow you and your friends to work as a cohesive unit. The gameplay is a refreshing kind of brutal where not keeping your head down will almost always result in your death. Objective battles are fantastic, and the ffa mode is one of the funnest i've ever played. In short, if you're looking for a unique shooter that is fun and won't break the bank, you've found it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Verdun is a multiplayer FPS, but unlike other games this one is set in WWI which gives it a different style. It isn't about running and gunning. The basis of the game is to attack and defend trenches which is very important, When the enemy attacks, the defenders must defend. This means that players must play the objective which doesn't always happen in games.
An important aspect of the game is that it is based around squads. Each player is in a squad and each member of that squad has different skills. Each squad also has an NCO who issues orders. Players are rewarded for working with their squad which increases the squad level and unlocks new equipment.
Overall this is a very fun game with a largely ignored setting but that is very interesting.

reviewText: Do you like the idea of Call of Duty, but hate the execution?  Do you like to mindlessly kill hordes of people, but think that all the other games that provide that experience suck?  Well Verdun is for you!  I have had this game for about 5 months now, and while it is not a game you put hundreds of hours into in that span of time, it is a great game to play casually in some down time.  I have only recently actually played it with friends, as the game was on sale and they finally bought it, and it is an even better experience!  The game is so addictive and immersive that you begin using callouts and other advanced strategies, no matter whether you wanted to or were conscious of the action or not.  Highly addictive, great fun alone, and an unimaginably awesome time with friends.  Solid 10/10, and there aren't even that many maps or guns, and it doesn't matter at all.  There could be 1 gun and 3 maps, and this game would still be 10/10.  Gameplay is amazing, and there are so many awesome moments that at times this game puts Battlefield to shame.  Must buy, especially on sale.  Would rather buy 4 more copies of this game for no reason than ever buy another Call of Duty in my life, because this game is so worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGamers of all strokes will find a role to enjoy in Verdun. Strategic movement is rewarded, and teamwork emphasized with the in game spawning mechanics. There are times where you will hear the whistle, stand up to leave the trench, and immediately collapse from a rifle shot. It only makes the final push more satisfactory. You may especially enjoy the back and forth dynamic, as defending and assaulting are quite different experiences. Performance during the waves dictates attackers/defenders respawn times and wave duration, rewarding a team which is able to efficiently elliminate many enemies. I would label this a 'Tactical FPS' though it lacks the typically strong learning curve of such games.

reviewText:

What about mud and flooded trenches?  I haven't played enough to tell but it appears the game does not have too many maps yet.  Where are the tunnels of WW1?

Overall though the game is a must have for anyone who enjoyed playing Red Orchestra games, or similar historic oriented 3D shooters.

reviewText:
This is a great change from the shooters we have been receiving recently. Where as other games are taking a futuristic approach to war with advanced technology and skills, Verdun takes you back to the early 1900's with an authentic feeling WWI feel.

Currently there are 2 different game modes to choose from, Frontlines, which is a squad based, team oriented game of capture the trench. In this game mode you must push the opposing team back out and away from their current holding and claim it as your own, or else they will be doing the pushing. The unique aspect of playing Frontlines is the aspect of attack and defend, and how it is handled as the rounds play out. If your team loses their hold on the trench, you are required to fall back to the previous trench and defend from there, hoping not to take a bullet in the back upon retreat. The active objective trench acts as a boundary where both sides can enter and fight for the claim by having more soldiers present (unless teams are unbalanced, this is compensated for). Teamwork is a MUST for a squad/team to succeed.

The other game type is a free-for-all Rifle Deathmatch, which it just what it sounds like. There are no worries of someone out-gunning you simply because they have bought a better gun or other concerns. Rifle Deathmatch is a true test of skills where everyone has a bolt action rifle, the same amount of ammo, and no individual has an upper-hand based on what you have in-game. There are some options, such as, the type of rifle (all authentic era styles) and very basic attachments. Would you rather have a bayonet for a 1-hit-kill melee, or perhaps a ranged scope for better distance shots? There are pros and cons to either choice.

All-in-all I rate this game very highly, and would recommend it to anyone and everyone who enjoys the FPS genre, it's a good change from the fast-paced shoot'em ups we have become accustomed to

reviewText: To my surprise, this game is actually very entertaining to play. That is to say, after you get past the steep learning curve. reviewText:
I started following Verdun back in 2011, when I first discovered it. Back then, it was thought to be Dead, Leo having moved on. All the footage we had was a short, soundless demo. The forums were nearly dead.

But then in 2013 something magical happened - It came back to life. There was a free Alpha, which was of the rifle deathmatch mode. It was fun, but showed SO much had to be done. And since then, so much has. This game is a tense, quasi-realistic FPS set in WWI, and as a WWI buff it has my seal of approval. It's fun, especially with friends. Playing with friends allows you to level up your squad together, and thus have access to newer uniforms, slight stat increases, and increased firepower (deadlier gas, more arty, etc...).

Seriously, this game needs and deserves more players. Buy it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When a game is Indie, some people think the game is not so good. When a game is at beta stage, some people think the game is not so good yet. Verdun is an Idie game at beta stage, and no matter what you think, the game is just great. Of course it has some glitches, and things to be improved, fixed or removed, but anyway, the game is just great. It like the only FPS game I've played about WWI (except for BF1918, but that was a mod). It is like some old shooters with bolt action rifles and one shot-one kill, but with an objective and squad based gameplay. As you can imagine, the main weapons are bolt action rifles, but there are also some other stuff like pistols, machine guns, grenades and mortar/artillery strikes. It makes you feel, when shooting with rifles, if you don't kill an enemy with this shot or if you miss, he is going to kill you. And it is usually that way. Sometimes it can be frustrating, when attacking an enemy trench and not being able to capture it, just like WWI, but it doesn't represent the horrors of trench warfare.
There is only one thing I don't like: there are too few players for a such a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Verdun is that special game that you will proably not see something like it for a long time if at all.

The Game is set in WW1 and is an FPS, the setting is nice and hardly ever done. Something I wish other games explored. The game tries to do its best to fit the setting. With songs from the era playing in the menu and people shouting in German and French as Mortar Shells and Rifles sound thorugh the battle.

Now gameplay wise the game is very simple. It's a squad based FPS. With 4 men squads consisting of 1 Officers and 3 Troops each with it's own specializations, unlocks and weapons difrent for each type of squad and each faction. The battles play out in a push defend way. One side attacks, the other defends if the attack succedes the other team has to push the enemy out if it fails they get to counter attack.

Gun play is very simple but yet fun. The game is set in WW1 so Most people Run around with a Rifle with the exception of MG's and Officers. You aim, fire and bolt. Repeat till you kill someone or have to reload then repeat the proccess till you are killed. The game adds flavour to this by adding Bayonets, Scopes and Grenades even Pistols to some Classes and Types of Soliders. All in all I found the gun play fun and entertaining.

Now on the bad side.

Graphics are mediocre. This doesn't bother me as in my PoV the gameplay makes up for it.
Sounds are mediocre as well but at least the weapons sound well enough.
Maps are repetitive so far but this is understandble as the game is Early Access.
Like any Early Access Game bugs are there and there isn't enough bug spray.


But over all the game has potential it is fun and you can clearly see what the devs want to develop this game into. But this game is not even half way finished. I would recomend you get it on sale or keep an eye out for the game to be fully released but as it stands at 20 Euro's its not worth it. Potential is there but there is not enough value at the moment for that price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You will not find a war game more demanding, dark and gritty than Verdun.  Although still rife with bugs and creases that need ironing out, it's a great game that I got a few months back.  Now with the increased player limit on the servers the matches are ferocious and intense.  There's little more satisfying than sitting on the edge of a trench with a machine gun mowing down frenchmen, sniping germans or calling in mortar strikes on enemy positions.

Although still being made, it's damn worth a purchase.

I choose to play this over AAA games like battlefield and most other shooting games.

Worth getting.

reviewText: Very hectic game that captures the danger of World War One for combat service members (historically, the war holds the record for greatest military casualty ratio)\n\nYou will die. Often. You will get shot across the map, and will shoot others across the map. It's a game of patience with a steep but satisfying learning curve and a community all about having fun. reviewText:
After only 9 hours of playing Verdun I can safely say its an incredable game and its still only in early beta stages. The game is divided into two different modes FRONTLINE is squads of four guys attacking trenches and trying to take them from the enemy you have 5-6 minutes to attack then you must defend for around that amount of time. Each class plays a great role in this game the riflemen pushes into the trench trying to take it the sniper kills with range and in my experience are the most deadly players the commanders or whatever you call them are greta being able to order strikes on weak points and call in morter strikes to sometimes great effects as for the machine gunner I have never seen anyone use it to great effect so I can't say anything about it. The tactics for FRONTLINE revolve around using your whole squad in a combined attack but since their is no voice chat yet this rarely happens ^^. As of now there is only four maps Picardee Vossges arrgonne and I always forget the last one they are all fairly fun to play on although I must admit Picardie is the most fun ;). The next form of game mode is RIFLE DEATHMATCH no not the crappy COD kind really nice FFA bolt-action rifle greatness no killstreaks and crap just good old fashioned fun. You get to pick one rifle you want to unlock and you get that you level it up and get new things. Moving on to the community I FREAKING LOVE THE COMMUNITY ON THIS GAME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Almost everyone in game and on the forums are incredably nice and helpful people offering new players tips and very rarely bad mouthing ( you notice I said rarely it does happen ;) ). I go on the forums vcet players ask me to play with them and they'd give me pointers really nice people online. Probably the funnest people on Verdun are the history buffs I love history and watching these people talk about French battle tactics ETC ETC ETC... is really fun and enjoyable. Moving on to Graphics how are they you ask? They are good I would tell you I myself don't care for graphics as long as the game is fun but I have to say the game is rather good looking the guns are well detailed and look amazing the facial textures and models are terrible but who cares when the gameplay is so fun. The graphics option menu has a bevy yes bevy of graphics optins which is very nice. Over all as a person who usually detests FPS games I find this game very enjoyable it has very few bugs that I have noticed there are a few graphics glitchs but these are rare, And what bugs there are a quickly being fixed by the amazing developers I have looked at posts of when this first came out in alpha and it was terrible but since then the three devs yes only three have worked hard adding new things and fixing bugs making this game very enjoyable. Overall I think this is the bet WW1 shooter your gonna find anywhere and I highly reccomend it to anyone even if you dislike FPS games like me I think you might enjoy this nice game. I hate giving scores but that what most people want but I won't because this is only a BETA everything I say might change in three days in a new patch so I won't bother to give it an overall score till it officially launchs but I still highly reccomend this game anyway I'm out have fun dying to snipers and the OP commander pistols PEACE!!!!!!!!!!!!!


EDIT: Game released yesterday and its amazing. Haven't played it since August of 2014. The graphics, gameplay, and new features all add a lot to the game.


Totally worth buying at full price. Only early access I have seen that is this loved by its devs.

reviewText:
Product received for free

In this review of Verdun I will be covering 5 catagories of gameplay (Which includes game community)

*** Preformance ***
Although the graphics aren't that of the new Battlefield 1 coming out, Verdun is a beautiful looking game for its content and context. If there is one annoyance I have it is the optimization of the game, I run a GTX 750Ti and I can run everything at high and some ultra, and I get about 40-45 FPS when I play, but I have read where some people with higher grade cards experiance lower or even wors frames, but for me it was fine with some drops in FPS the lowest I have had being was 20 FPS but that was at the beginning of a map when everything renders. One other annoyance that ties into community and preformance, some players turn landscape and foliage quality off or too low to get an edge on players, where as if you were hiding in bushes on your screen, on another players with no foliage you would be laying in open ground. Over all preformance out of 10 would be a 7.5, due to the time it has been out and has been repatched time and time again.

*** Gameplay ***
The key factor Blackmill was going for in this game was realism and authentisity, and I think they hit that mark to a certain degree, which it is real and fun for both sides fighting. The guns are authentic and so are the squads and languages spoken. I understand if they really wanted to make it realistic by taking out UI and making friendly fire a thing but Blackmill I am assuming wanted to make new players feel welcome without being too harsh in gameplay. Over all score would be a 9 out of 10, the gameplay is spot on with the weaponry mechanics and realism.

*** Mechanics ***
The mechanics and such for Verdun are average for me. Running is a little clunky and the default keys to crouch and sprint with are assigned in a very weird place, so I rebound crouch to CTR and sprint to SHIFT. However aside from movement mechanics, the bullet mechanics are well made for a 32 player trenchwarfare FPS, there is bullet drop at long range and if you want a kill while the enemy is rushing toward you at an angle you gotta know how to lead your shots. Over all I give mechanics a clunky but not too shabby 7 out of 10.

*** Realism *** (In a sense of immersion)
Verdun is spectacular at immersifying me into the trenches of World War I. Sometimes when the artillery is soaring over head i'll take a second to look up, as I hear the yelling of other soldiers in the trench next to me, and there is a certain type of peace as well, looking at the whistiling wizz-bangs overhead. But me gawking usually ends with a German putting a Luger round throught the back of my head, pulling me back to reality, Oh
date:
I died. Damn."
A solid 9/10

*** Community ***
The Verdun community is very welcoming with most people
recommended: even to noobs at the game
hoursPlayed: dont be afraid to ask questions in all chat
voteText: usually a few people will tell you the answer to put your gas mask on. But the unfortunate part about Verdun is the size of the community
helpfulPercent: its fairly small for such an awesome game
votesHelpful: but I am seeing more people playing because of the recent announcement of Battlefield 1
votesTotal: which is good and possibly bad for Blackmill
votesFunny: but Verdun will always hold a place as one of my most favorite games ever. I am veering off track but
commentsCount: the Verdun community is spectacular

reviewText:
Early Access Review

excellent game if you like military history, even though the graphics may feel kind of arcadish, they have improved and they probably will improve until the final game is released. this is one of a kind, the only game that is kind of red orchestra/battlefield-such that you can play battles situated in world war one. currently there are only germany and france, but it is likely that great britain and some other nations will be added. it is a lot of fun to play. the first person shooter elements are definitely authentic if not the best, and there is hardly any spraying bullets in the game because most of the people are using bolt-action rifles.

currently there are two kinds of squads for both germany and france: regular army squads and mountain infantry squads, there are 4 people in each squad. NCO(commander/officer), gunner, machine gunner, grenadier mountain infantry wield shorter, faster-firing rifles, better for shorter range engagements, and they have superior stamina, their officers have recon plane abilities that can reveal enemy locations on the map. regular army squads have 4 people as well but they are better for long-range engagements, their officers have mortar strike abilities.

the game is set around trench warfare, you will either defend or attack a position. if you accomplish the objective, you earn a point as a team. therefore, the match scores are usually like soccer game scores.

there is also a deathmatch mode where you unlock your own rifles and attachments.

pros:

-authentic gameplay,trench warfare
-decent visuals
-unique game
-concerned developers, even though there is a grand total of 3 of them

cons:

-bugs and stuff. your progress may get reset.
-certain roles are picked up by people who have absolutely no clue what they are doing...if your officer does not advance, you keep spawning on him, and you will have to walk a lot. it can get quite annoying
-no automatic team balancing, you can have plenty of games where there is twice as much of the enemy,mostly french outnumbering german teams
-french rifles have better sights than german rifles. thus, it is easier to hit targets with them. this causes balancing issues where most of the great players will prefer shooting with french rifles. i always play as both german and french and get kills easier with french rifles at range

reviewText:
What can I say... the graphics on this game could be a lot better. That said I don't know of any game on steam that quite captured the essence of WW1 trench warefare, it's futility, it's brutality, it's sheer mindnumbing horror. You stay in the trench, you get an artillery round and your dead, you stick your head up to have a look, you get your head shot off, you jump out of the trench to attack across no mans land you get shot... you go the wrong way you can caught up in barded wire you get shot or die...

you get the picture....

Great game... the graphics need a bit of work.. but awesome game if you feel like some self traumatisation every now and again.

reviewText:
This game is not finished. If it is, then the developers simply do not know how to make a game. Major issues for me:

Spawn-killing. This is majorly ♥♥♥♥ing frustrating. On several maps you can be killed a second after spawn by a player with an MG or Sniper Rifle. This is extremely frustrating, especially when your entire team spawns back at the same time and then all get killed a second later by an MG.

The game has massive problems with lag. I've not played a game without someone jumping around all laggy. It happens too often with too normal ping observed for it to be the players problem.

The hitboxes seem kind of wonky, coupled with the lag make it frustrating when you clearly hit someone only to have them lag-teleport elsewhere. Even without the lag I find shots that clearly hit not even registing a hit.

The character class system is annoying and damages the WW1 asthetic. There are 16 players per side. There are 16 classes per side, for a totaly of 32. All are different. Most lack basic things like grenades or a bayonet. Only one person can play a class at a time, so you can't have most people playing a grenadier - likely you would just have 2-3 per team. It's needlessly complicated, especially when each squad has a different uniform representing a different nation so you have to learn 8 different infantry uniforms and 8 different officer uniforms.

There are problems with the terrain. I don't know what causes it, it's certainly not my computer, but the terrain will only partially loads in. It's not a draw distance thing, because terrain behind it loads in perfectly. But I see a dude's head pop-over a hill, shoot it, only to find I get nothing by the bullet-hits-ground effect. Sure enough, I take a few steps forward and the hill in between use loads a foot higher than it was, and that's what was seperating us.

See through terrain, related to the previous point. You can't shoot through it.

Barbwire is handled poorly. One small contact with your leg starts killing you. I've been killed without realizing I'm caught  on any because it was so small that I didn't even see it. Also, jumping over it is a waste. Apparently stepping on with thick army boots won't stop it from tearing your flesh? It could've been handled better is my point.

Game feel. There is next to none. No sloshy mud, no soldiers cussing as they reload, no screaming deathrattles, no weather, no nothing. It feels like an empty, quite world devoid of anything that makes me feel like I'm part of it.

There are other issues, but I can't recall them right now. I'll update if I remember anything new.

I feel like the developers are lying when they said this game was out of beta and finish. I feel ripped off because the game is clearly not finished or polished. I feel you would be better off saving your money.

It has a unique theme, has great concepts, maps and the uniforms look good, and the whole trench and rifle madness just work out.
Then what does make it a horrible game ?
The netcode of course. Simply has the worst netcode in a pvp game i have ever seen. Players randomly teleporting all over the place, shots go through enemies, getting killed behind cover. Synchronization is plain bad.
The character animations look horrible and clunky. Melee system is awful, it automatically locks the target.
The first time i say, but this game really needs Frendly fire. On small maps, like Argonne, artillery and nade spam makes a mindless explosive fest.

Edit: Plus The Horrors of War DLC introduced more balance issues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr: If you like FPS and WW1 you can't go wrong with this game. While lacking a bit of depth gameplay-wise it's still a solid shooter on it's own and the unique setting definitly makes this worth buying.

As someone who played this games early, early pre-alpha, when it still was browser based I have to say it improved greatly.
There has been A LOT of new content and even a few new game mechanics and to me this shows that the developers definitly have a vision for  this game. But now for the actual review:

Gameplay:
I won't lie the gameplay is more or less generic shooter, the gunplay definitly is. Sure bolt-action rifles are uncommon in FPS but by no means completely new. The Squad mechanic is a nice little feature, it actually makes you bond a bit with the people you play, IF you or them don't leave the squad after a few minutes, which is why I'm not sure whether or not the join-in-progress mechanic was a good idea. Verdun lacks the depth of a Red Orchestra concerning health and wounds and the movement system is a bit clunky compared to RO, this shows especially when you try to make your way through No-Mans-Land and get hit because you didn't crouch as fast as you wanted.
Even though this does sound rather harsh I don't mean to discredit the game. If you have any experience with shooters you won't find this game to be very different, apart from the obvious fact that the weapons aren't full auto of course. It's real strength (for now) isn't the gameplay but the setting. Also I have faith that the Devs know about these 'issues' and will address them in the future.

Setting and Environment:
Like I said this is what makes this game unique: the World War 1 setting. The Equipment is highly detailed and fairly accurate, and so are the uniforms. The maps are ugly, muddy wastelands, full of craters, wire and tranches which really sells the setting. The maps are also rather diverse, ranging from true trench-riddled wastelands, where lurking over the top will get you killed in a few seconds, to rather open maps which feature a little less deadly razor-wire and a bit more nature.
This game only features the western front, where most of the gruesome trench warfare took place. One can play as either different German squads as well as French, English and Canadians. The Voice-acting is rather good, with all sides featuring good, propably even native, and diverse voice actors. This may not seem like a big deal, but nothing helps me more to create immersion than an angry british NCO yelling to 'get my ♥♥♥ over the top and smoke out the bloody jerries'

Graphic:
While I don't care too much for good graphics, this game looks rather nice but is has really bad optimisation, be warned.

I would also like to add that this games has one of the best main-menu screens I ever encountered, but you'll see what I mean by that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is holy amazing. It is based off of World War I, and it has a lot of trench combat and squads. There is a good amount of weapons for you to use. There are different rifles, pistols, machine guns, and melee weapons. Some weapons can get attachments like scopes and bayonets. It requires a good deal of teamwork. Often attacking a trench or defending a trench alone will result in a nice simple death. You need teammates to help cover you.

It may be hard to get used to at first, but if one playstyle isn't working, try another. If you've been talking an assault playstyle most of the time, next time give a flanking playstyle next time and so on. That's how I became a bit better at the game. It's still hard to learn, but it's very fun to play. When you kill a guy it feels so darn satisfying.

reviewText:
This game, is absolutely amazing.
While not exclusively in Verdun, It's literally THE Best WW1 game I've ever played. Which to be honest isn't really saying much because there are only few I can really mention right now. Sadly other developers of games think it's a boring time to make games, which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to me, being deeply interested in the timeframe and the history behind all of the nations. But It's a very great game nonetheless. It has mechanics that absolutely match the setting of the game, 1 hit from a rifle means you're most likley going to die, although 2 shots that means you're lucky and just stay in cover and hopefully your ally can save you or the enemy who shot you gets distracted or something.

There are 3 mechanics that make it one of my favourite games I've played this year...

1- Bullet mechanics
As I've mentioned bullets do extreme amounts of damage and you can't just go run out in the open like Rambo/CoD style like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however there is also bullet drop in the game, along with the foggening of the screen and more of a dark tunnel when being shot at rather jelly blood literally being thrown at your face when bein shot, which adds more of the WW1 feel about being in a trench. Which makes a Pistol really deadly in a trench, and a machine gun a beast when shooting at attackers, and the rifle is a good weapon to use all around depending on how you use it

2- Atmosphere/Map design
As well a prior statement, however with this I mean by when your running through the trenches, it makes mud sounds when running through them, and even makes it awesome when artillery fires on it and you need to duck and cover from it or you will 99% of the time die. However, No mans land is even more awesome to run through durring an assault on the enemy trench, because you have to worry about barbed wire ripping your legs apart and being left on the field for dead, or using artillery craters as cover because small abandoned, unfinished trenches can't guide you the whole way. Another reason not to run out as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rambo/4 Year old CoD player.

3- Chemical Warfare Use
My Personal favourite part of the game is the fact that there is different gasses used such as mustard gas, or chlorine gas on the battlefield against your enemies or at you and your allies. What really makes it interesting is that you can go through it so long as you have your gas mask on and you aren't being currently shot at. It doesn't even just come and go also, it stays and lingers the area of impact for about 3-4 minutes and if you die and spawn in it, you need to get your mask on fast or you will certainly die. It's not scripted on each map thankfully, there are special units that can call it in like calling in artillery or commanding squad members, so it will either appear multiple times in one battle or none at all.  That's really on your own opinion whether it's bad or good though.

And that's really it, I got the game the day before I made this review, and I think it's better than most of the CoD's combined already. Other than it being a WW1 game, the 3 game mechanics are the best I've seen in a long while. So I highly recommend this game for the stated reasons. The only problems I've seen so far is the body mechanics on when people die, and the melee weapons are a bit overranged, like a small shiv can reach like an officers sword which is strange. But nonetheless this is the greatest WW1 shooter ever made in my opinion. I hope the're a lot of people who agree with me and I don't doubt it at all, considering the countless of positive reviews aside from mine.

Final Rating: 9/10 for Verdun

Personaly, what makes this game for me is the uniforms; the amount of detail is outstanding. The devs themselfs seem like great folks. It is very obvious that they love this game and value its community. They have also anounced that they will continue to support this game with new content once they have completed it. This content will feature aditions such as blood and gore mechanics, new game modes and maps, and perhapes the most anticipated, new factions. the USA is sloted for the first release in the form of both US Marines as well as US army. The german army will also be expanded to balance the two sides with the Pioner Squad that will bring the flame thrower to the battle field.
This game is a rare gem for those that enjoy atmospher and realistic game play. Anyone coming from a more arcade style shooter may fined the learning curve a bit steep, however i would say that this game is hard to pick up or unfair to new players. It just takes practice and patiance. Once you figure it out its very addicting.
Ill close with one con (because i can really only think of one). Right now it seems that the net code could use a bit of polish. There are a few games ware you will experiance some stutering and isolated telaporting of the enemy and your team mates. this con will obviously be less of a problem for those with strong internet, but i figured that is was worth mentioning. All in all though, a real solid game

reviewText:
Fun lil trench warfare shooter. It's not quite Red Orchestra and it's definately not like COD. This game is a slower paced, semi-realistic shooter with some lovely sound and graphics to boot. The community is respectful, people tend to know what to do, and if you're a noob you likely will not be berated for it.

Overall, this game reminds me of my days playing paintball with its one-shot-one-kill mechanic and having to use the land (as opposed to boxes/buildings/walls) as cover. It's hard to see enemies and if you're leaving yourself out in the open you can consider yourself as good as dead. I often find myself looking for vantage points where I can shoot a couple times and then leave as to not leave myself open to return fire. It's a tense environment, yet deceptively relaxing and not many games pull of this feeling for me.

For the price, why not give it a spin? You might be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is getting better and better (Beta V164), I really do look forward to the new features coming from that indeed small developer team - again hats off!

Verdun is comparable to Red Orchestra and the classic Call of Dutys. The gameplay, involving capturing enemy terrain, is pretty simple and can be learnt is a couple of minutes. Mastering i,t though, is another thing. You'll be dying pretty often if you don't make efficient use of trenches, craters and other forms of cover. Then there's the gas, machine guns, mortar strikes, .....

Some details need a bit of refinishing though, like the interface for switching sides (pressing TAB+ESC in-game is quite awkward if you ask me) or the use of the Command features like calling in mortar strikes. Maybe a tutorial would be a help to confused newcomers?

Anyway, if you're looking for a decent Multiplayer-FPS based in World War One, then Verdun is your first choice by now. And it's getting better with every update!

reviewText:

If you are a fan of FPS and looking for a fresh new game to play, you should try Verdun, it's a whole new FPS experience !

reviewText:
Stand up to look around for enemy - Shot...

Over the top, sprint through no mans land - Shot...

Over the top, sprint and hide in crater - Mortared...

Over the top, sprint and hide in crater, get tired trying to sprint to another crater - Shot...

Over the top, sprint and hide in crater, crawl to next crater - Grenaded...

Over the top, sprint and hide in crater, wait for gas, crawl to next crater,  jump into their trench  - Stabbed...

Over the top, sprint and hide in crater, gas still everywhere, crawl to next crater, wait for squad, we all jump in trench - We made it!

And that was the easy part, now we have to clear it.

10/10 would die again.

tl;dr
-Play smart - if you keep dying trying to do the same thing try something different.
-Use teamwork - this is fundamental to the game, it is tailored to help you find people you work well with and playing with them.
-Know your squad's and position's role - using their strengths and finding ways around their weaknesses is key.
-Enjoy this awesome game!  Don't give up, it's so worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor an indie game still in development, Verdun is pretty well done. It is a First World War fps based around the French-German battle of Verdun in 1916. I'm going to say this straight off the block, the game it seems most like, is Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad, just with lesser quality graphics, less polished gameplay, and funny running animations. This is not a bad thing. Infact it is a good thing in my eyes, whilst not being a big fps fan I was able to enjoy this due to my enjoyment of RO2. The game puts you in squads of 4 men, one person in each squad plays a different class from NCO's, Riflemen, Machine gunners, and Grenadiers and your aim is to keep pushing your enemy back through the lines of trenches, without losing your own. Straight from this you can tell the developers are encouraging teamplay, which is a very good sign. The system works ok on the overall, as you attack a trench, if you take it before the time limit you defend it from counter-attack before moving on, if you fail to attack it you have to defend against a counter-attack also, pretty basic. However I believe the spread of classes into classes that were not very common in WW1 has caused this to change slightly. The 4 man squad 1 per class has meant that 25% of the battlefield are each class, now whilst this goes for teamworking balanced gameplay it lacks that WW1 stalemate kind of authenticity where you get riflemen (the common conscript taking up a large percentage of the army) charging in masses against an enemy trench, clearly in view, getting mowed down by machine gun fire. This means you instead get people sitting around in shell holes with machine guns and shooting at the defenders who can't move far unless they are executed for deserting" when the machine gunner should be attacking. Whilst I would have loved to see the masses of soldiers charging over no-mans land to the sound of the officers whistle with machine gun fire rattling and men falling head over heels all around you
date: it is something we have to live with and is evident that is not the path the developers have chosen
recommended: it would be hard for that anyway with the terrain being so devastated. My only other grope with the game is the fact that it is purely based on Verdun (hear me out)
hoursPlayed: as whilst this is intentional

purely for the light hearted (I meant the gameplay not truth behind it) gameplay.

My rating: 7/10

Buy it if you appreciate that it is still under development

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the First World War setting gives an element of novelty to this online multiplayer shooter, what is truly innovative is the ebb and flow that is baked in to the gameplay. At any one time one side is in their trench defending, not allowed to advance towards the enemy, while the other side is in their own parallel trench being forced to run, crawl and walk over no-man's land towards their (almost) certain doom. Once the attackers reach the enemy trench it becomes a tense game of nerves as danger lurks around every corner. Succeed in capturing the trench and the enemy fall back to another; fail and you are sent back to your own trench to this time defend. In this way a map is played across a set of parallel trenches with advance and fallback, capture and defend.

The first world war elements are all there - bolt action rifles, hand guns, primitive hand grenades, mustard gas & gas masks, binoculars to spy the enemy position and calling up of mortar strikes. And the maps are full of mud, duckboards, sandbags, bomb craters and burnt out tanks and crashed bi-planes - truly desolate. The sound track is full of French and German commands and cries, with whistles alerting you to your officer's commands.

It's a truly innovtive game and well worth a try. Do yourself a favour and buy the multi-pack and share the love.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With a lot of the early Access games coming out I've noticed that it can be very difficult to judge progress within the given title. If you've only ever had the pleasure of seeing this game on steam, you may fall under this statement. Originally this was a browser based game and the amount of distance it has covered since then is substantial.

Has it been polished to a shining gem capable of reflections? No, but its a great example of what the early access section is capable of; Marked improvement over the duration of its development. It has a lovely community, and the devs listen and provide feedback, covering issues the community sees as most important (bullet drop is a great example).

The settings are great and immersive, bleak and unwelcoming. The gameplay is unique and really hits a niche with its first world war era backdrop. Charging trenches with grenades and bayonets, then defending against onslaughts of furious counter-attacks is thrilling.

Now I do admitt, the price tag is a little steep, though it isnt to waste. This has the potential to be a great full release, and as of me writing at this moment, it WILL be a great title. Spend the money and help us make it that shining gem that reflects our gleaming smiles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr -> If you want a WWI trench warfare simulator, then look no further. Machinegunner was mowing down our troops, so we called for a mortar strike on his position and rushed the trenches. Enemy responded with a gas attack on the immediate area, but we were able to get our masks on in time. Our attack wave ended, so we had to double back and repel the enemy advance. 11/10 for gritty realism.

I got this game gifted to me, and was looking forward to a chance to dive back into the competitive FPS genre. I was very satisfied with the work-in-progress, and am hopeful for the future direction of the game.

If you like WWI trench warfare, brutal, unforgiving combat, and heavy teamwork (player interaction is more Battlefield-style than Call of Duty's lone wolf, rambo playstyle), then you will enjoy this game. Although the game is very much an early-access product, the development seems strong and consistent, and there is definitely a lot of potential here.

The aesthetics are pretty good - the amount of detail in the environment is well-done, and the textures have a decent amount of work put in. There isn't any music, however, the  sound assets are fantastic - with practice, you can even distinguish which kind of weapons are being fired just from hearing it. I tried going underwater and firing my weapon, and the sound changes accordingly. Hiding underwater and listening to the difference in gunshots when you come up is pretty cool. The grenade mechanic - if one goes off next to you - is very good, and shooters can even sneak up on you while if they are careful.

The controls are typical of your generic competitive FPS, and don't take a long time to get used to. There is no tutorial, but there are plenty of helpful members in the community willing to help you out if you just ask. Matchmaking can be a bit confusing at first, but understand that each unique squad (Canadians, Germans, etc) have their own set of 4 classes to choose from, and your squad-class-specific experience carries between matches. Higher levels in a class unlock better loadouts - for example, I reached level 2 in a rifleman class and unlocked a sniper scope. Squads can also level up, and they will receive things like mortar/gas strike abilities. Classes have a maximum of 4 levels to unlock.

The checks and balances (trade-offs) are very impressive in this game. If you use the sniper scope, for example, it will increase your viewing range significantly, however, it will almost completely eliminate your peripheral view - making it easier for people to sneak past/toward you. Machinegunners are a menace to the trenches, but are easy rifle fodder because of the large muzzle flash they create. The Canadian squad is lightly armed with mostly pistols, however, they are excellent trench rushers and flankers. You can try jumping over barbed wire fences, but if you get stuck or land in one you will take significant damage.

During gameplay, you will have to alternate between attack/defend waves, which require the attacking team to try to capture structures or critical areas by having more soldiers within. When the wave timer runs out, the roles will switch, and any attackers caught too deep in enemy territory are automatically executed (defenders also cannot run out too far). You will most likely die from a single rifle/machinegun shot, but can take one or two extra pistol hits. Combat is very satisfying, especially if you can get into a superior firing/kill position overlooking the enemy.

Overall, if you are interested in historical trench warfare, I would strongly suggest you check out this game. I look forward to what the developers have in store for the future.

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

reviewText: Verdun has a lot of great ideas.  Yes, it's definitely not for everyone, but the immersion and setting are astounding.  Core gameplay is fun if not frustrating.  Dying over and over is OK, even expected.  What's more important is objective play.  Gameplay consists of two teams wrestling for land, using a timer system.  Capture the trench and you then must prepare for the counter-attack.  Lose a trench, and you must retreat and regroup.  Dropping people from long-range is extremely gratifying when you pull it off.  There isn't a ton of room for creativity due to it's era, but what's there feels true to form and genuine.  Have your NCO call in a artillery strike, or mustard gas, throw on your gas mask while the enemy is still confused, and start stabbing them with your bayonet.  This game is one-shot-one-kill unless you're using a pistol or MG.  Liken it to similar FPS's like Red Orchestra 2.\n\nWhat's holding Verdun back from being great?  Not lack of content or creativity, a game about the war that coined the term trench warfare" is to be expected.  It's optimization.  Frequent stutters and dropped frames hinders this game's immersion and playability greatly.  Optimizing your game should not be "turning everything off".  This game is incredibly CPU heavy
date: a quad-core CPU is absolutely required for a smooth experience.\n\nWith these glaring performance issues
recommended: I simply cannot recommend Verdun despite it's extremely gratifying core gameplay."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting for a WWI FPS for years and this is the best that I've been able to find and for what it is right now, despite its flaws, it's pretty effing good.  I've always had a grim fascination with the Great War and think myself to be a bit of a buff.  The guns, classes, the desolation and destruction are all very well done.  The ambient noise (the shouting, the planes flying overhead) can be pretty eerie.

It is patched and updated fairly regularly and I can only see it getting better.

One of the best things about it?  From what I've seen, the people who play it/that I've played with are some of the nicest I've encountered in a long time.  That could be worth the price of the game itself.

I wish only the absolute best for the Verdun team.  Buy the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

8.2/10
+weapon and setting detail (simply amazing)
+huge maps offer diverse gameplay
+unique gameplay, never seen an fps quite like it

-weird animations on some occasions
-no real incentive to stay with your squad at first
-few maps (for now I guess)
-potentially low frame rates
-Lacks certain forms of realism (which I guess is due to everyone trying to play individually)
Summary: This is a game intended for different types of people if you are looking for some realistic fps set in world war 1 then you may not get what you want, if you are searching for a completed game with tons of maps and a huge community your wishes might not be fulfilled. If you are looking for a balance of the two then you should buy Verdun asap. I believe that in most cases it is well worth your money. Lots of fun and the quality of the game is getting better by the week.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the only WWI games out there, and certainly the best. Squad combat is great and the different roles feel unique. However, it's the Front-Lines Game-mode that really makes this game shine. One team has to capture a trench or position. While the opposition has to hold them back. Either way, the attacking team has to face a counter attack, whether it's from they old lines after being beaten back, or simply the new one they've just taken!

However, this is an early access game. It does have a few problems. Some of the weapons such as the MG's can take a bit to get to, even after selecting that class. The animations are still a little shoddy too.

But, overall. I have to recommend this game if you have interest in anything WWI related, the fighting is simply to well done to not recommend. You can try and sneak into a relatively weak are of defense, or run out like a madman lobbing grenades everywhere.

reviewText:
Verdun is a very fun objective based shooter. You battle through the trenches, attacking or defending based on your teams momentum. If as an attacker you manage to push into a forward trench and hold it, then the enemy will be forced to retreat to a further back trench. While advancing or retreating you may find yourself in no man's land, where explosions and gunfire tend to tear you apart, but it's still exciting when you survive. There is a good mixture of camping and rushing, due to the offense and defense phases.

The classes are predefined, so you can't use whatever weapons you want. They are locked to different squad types, and to the different classes within those squad types. For example, a squad leader might only have a pistol, but they also have he ability to call in an artillery strike which can make the difference between holding objectives or not. I personally think it's a good move to have weapons locked to classes, because that eliminates the possibility for everyone to just use machine guns. It allows for a good variety of weaponry on the battlefield, and gives use to the squads.

It's by no means perfect, and there are really annoying querks like not being able to shoot through barbed wire that happen at times, but overall it's highly enjoyable. Patches come out frequently, and it really feels like the developers are doing/want to do the best they can with it. I certainly recommend it, especially if you have a group of friends you can squad up with.

reviewText: Finally a good World War 1 game! Experience the great war with all the bolt action, trench warfare, chemical weapon fighting you want! As of this review there are a deathmatch and Front lines. The Front lines game mode requires a little bit more explaining. I am going to quote the wiki here for you guys new to the game.\n\nFrontlines is the most popular type of match played in Verdun. It is a competition between two teams
date: one French and one German. Each team has up to sixteen players. Each team is divided into squads of up to four players. The teams alternate between offense and defense ("Attack" vs "Defend"). While on offense the team can score a point by capturing the next trench. If the defending team is able to successfully defend their trench from the attack
recommended: then they earn a point. The match ends when one team controls the entire map or the timer runs out. "\n\nThere is a lot of detail put into Verdun
hoursPlayed: but it does have a small playerbase at the moment. The game itself reminds me a bit of the Red Orchestra games in a World War 1 setting. Overall I have got to say I really recommend Verdun
voteText: its just got what it takes to be a great game!"

reviewText: So here I am, Corporal in command of the 18th Royal Infantry squad, Vosges. Me and the lads are making a heroic effort to hold back the German offensive... So many men paid the price for me, the NCO. The rolemodel. No more, I will take this trench back. The German scum shall be driven back to the filthy holes they crawled out from. I vault over the barbed wire into what had been our trench mere minutes ago. My Lee Enfield fired three times, all three cutting a German down. Then comes the part that haunts me, I began to stab into the Germans with my bayonet, they screamed in agony, but I continued my savage assault. I requested for mortars to be fired on my location in an attempt to kill off the last of the Germans in my trench. I began to stab more and more, I had lost track after the twelfth German had fallen. I had driven them back, the trench was ours. I was a hero, then a whistle and a boom. My mortar landed on my head.\n10/10\nWould Rambo mode and suicide again

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVerdun is absolutely amazing for an alpha. The game demonstrates trench warfare perfectly, while the whistle blows I'd hop over the trench and charge the enemy under machine gun fire. Once in the trench, the enemy would drop gas and I'd put my gas mask on. Then my squad and I would take the trench and prepare to charge for the next one. It makes me feel like I'm actually there. This game is entirley unique because, sadly, there are barely any fps set in WW1 out right now. Some cons about the game are the fps. I have a high-end gaming rig and I still manage to get 20-40 fps depending on the map. I know this is still in alpha but I'd like it fixed. Some things I'd like to see in the game are aerial dogfights, and more gore. I think it would look awesome to look up and see planes firing at eachother. But I would definetly like to see more blood and gore the most. It would be more immersive to be pinned down in a blood filled with guts flying everywhere, considering how brutal and rutheless WW1 was. Overall, I do recommend this game in it's current state. I'm sure the devs will fix the fps issue and add more content later on. I rate 8/10.
