reviewText:
One of the most original, fun, beautiful, creative games from the last years. It combines authenticity with playability.
The game is realistic. Does the occasional glitchy stuff happen, yes Newton didn't get an apple macbook on his head, physics don't always apply. So yes this game is probably as realistic as it should/can be. It handles this realism very well, it is a fun game that is also realistic. You get shot, you die. But it's not that you get shot every 2 seconds. No, people are realisticly shown at distances, rifle and handgun mechanics too. You simply cannot shoot someone, if it is not possible.
Please if you have the possibility to buy this or try this, please do.
Not everyone can like it but if you like something fresh/exciting for a change, Go for it!

reviewText:
Absolutely Terrific.

There aren't many Great War games out there and this one manages to pull off what a lot of AAA titles are afraid to do. Extremely challenging and terrifyingly realistic this game is well worth the price. Each kill is extremely satisfying and worth the effort. If you're looking for a good K/D...this probably isn't the game for you. You will die. A lot. But I still keep coming back despite my enormous death toll because the game mechanics are so fun.

Today they also came out with a free expansion for the game. That is great for multiple reasons. First off, you get more content and it is free. But secondly it means the Devs are still passionate about their game which doesn't happen very often with small early access games. I've had this game from day one of early access and it has honestly ceased to amaze me. Great buy! Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Fun bolt-action shooter that requires some patience to play and either quick reflexes or a good eye. Strongest part of the game is that it is very team-based; victory predicates on your team working together, not on kills.

Guns are fun enough to shoot and have minor variations, but as all rifles are one shot kills, the only real differences are clip size, rate of fire, and sightings. Pistols are fun but useless at range, MG's are powerful and are excellent defensive weapons that must be setup to be useful. There is no need to worry about weapons overheating, however, so they can be a bit lacking in depth.

Poison gas is a very cool element of this game and does a great job of mixing up a fight, bringing everyone into close-range shootouts and melees and blocking line of sight.

Map selection is limited, but I do believe more are planned. Their individual quality is surprisingly good considering they are mostly made up of pot-holes and trenches.

Performance wise Verdun runs OK but tends to have variable performance even on higher end systems with medium graphics settings.

Overall a solid purchase for anything under $20. $23 is acceptable, but this is a game you know will go on sale for deep discounts.

reviewText:
Verdun is an amazing game. It's a huge breath of fresh air from all the terrible historical games that follow the formula of: you are the Mary Sue American hero, that is the evil German Nazi, kill the Nazi, you've saved the world. It gives you a chance to see that war from all sides and better yet it actually has more factions that America. In fact, they don't have America at all! In terms of Entente powers you have British Tommies, Canadians (a rare sight in gaming), and two different French divisions. In terms of Central powers you have three different German divisions. It certianly gives you a wide variety of choices. At last a good game about World War 1!

Pros:
-diverse gameplay
-wide variety of faction choices
-interesting squad level system
-artillery!
-gets away from the stantard good guy/bad guy formula

Cons:
-some maps favor snipers very heavily
-French rifles are absolutely terrible but that is something that is out of the developers' control
-some odd situations where you're sitting in a shell hole or a trench and you get killed through a hill and a few meters of solid dirt and sandbags

Wishes:
-Austrio-Hungarian factions
-Anzac troops
-Vehicles and weapons for dealing with them (not sure about this one)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a ton of potential.

This a great squad based first-person tactical shooter that punishes you again and again for the decisions you make (and don't). This game is not for the lone wolves out there. You assuredly will die by a K98 or SMLE fire and your corpse will jiggle on the barbed wire.

You will die following your buddies breaching trenches too. A stray bullet whizzes past your comrades into your heart. Your last breath is a 3rd person view of your comrades awkwardly running into the trench avenging your death!  How glorious.

You will die by artillery. You will spawn again in 20 seconds and be killed by artillery. You will be an NCO and call artillery on the enemy positions. You will not kill anyone with your artillery.

Sometimes, though, sometimes you don't die. Sometimes you get the drop on your target. Sometimes your artillery lands and nets 5 kills. Sometimes your charge following your artillery barrage means you caught the enemy by surprise and 5 types of blood wet your bayonet or trench shovel.

The game is just so much fun. Be patient, be cooperative, and press shift to hold your breath for accurate fire!

The real mastery of the game comes in how you play each class. NCOs should stay back and provide themselves as support/safe spawn to keep attacks fresh. Machine gunners should find perfect vantage points and fire down on reinforcements...

Great game.

reviewText: This game is pretty good overall for what I have played.  If you are looking for a high speed twitch shooter then this game isn't for you.  That said it has plenty of action, a good mix of strategy, detailed maps, and a fun squad based system.  That said, you definitely want to bring your friends for this one, being in a squad with people you play well with will increase the enjoyment of this game immensely since so much revolves around the squad gameplay.  Rough around the edges, but solid at its core Verdun is a game I feels bring some freshness to the otherwise stale modern FPS genre and will keep playing it well into the future.

reviewText:
To be short. Devs added new features in good old FPS shooter:
4 Squads, each 4 players. Each player has a role. And 4 squads in team that has a role too — spotters, close quarters, supports. Finally someone made a true frontline game. Ain't this points that we see everywhere. Something fresh!
Atmosphere is great. For a first time multiplayer game that depress you with fears and terrors of war. For real, I feel Remarque's spirit in this game. Sometimes when you run from trench to trench, you think — why I'm doing this, what is the reason, why I have to kill another people, but then you getting're you unlock...

Worthy game, especialy on sale. More stuff to come, watch xmas truce event — dat is gorgeous.
----
Update 16.01.15
Devs repolished engine, now it's Unity 5. New sound, animations, supression and shellshock features.
----
Update 27.10.15
Stability increased. Game came out from Early Access. So how it plays?

It's a son of Insurgency + Red Orchestra 2. Better then Insurgency but not so polished like RO2. U got no tanks here on the battlefield and only 32 players. Weapons are good, you feel them. Game has it's own atmosphere of trench's warfare. Frontline mode -- first you attack then you hold. Devs cut the nerve -- you really feel the insanity of war. You keep dying trying to reach trench, then you got to fall back and it's infinite. I read Remarque's book about WWI and it's really that feel.

But if you pass this period you will get E.Junger experience. You will start love that insanity. Trench's massacre, close quarters battle rage.
Also each map is different. In 1914 it's more about rifle shootings, in 1918 -- class quarters in trenches.

+ Weapons
+ Well designed historical clothes
+ Balance -- you need to teamplay
+ Frontline mode
+ Devs learn a lot about WW1
+ Speed Bolting

= Not for everyone.

- Glitch sometimes
- Only 32 players
- Bad VoIP
- No tanks, cars.


I'm looking forward that Devs will continue shape and add new features like they did in early access. Great road from more mode than game to Insurgency 2 level game.

05.12.15
Fixed review. Found that there are speed bolting like in RO2. Check it in options

reviewText:
Verdun is a very fun objective based shooter. You battle through the trenches, attacking or defending based on your teams momentum. If as an attacker you manage to push into a forward trench and hold it, then the enemy will be forced to retreat to a further back trench. While advancing or retreating you may find yourself in no man's land, where explosions and gunfire tend to tear you apart, but it's still exciting when you survive. There is a good mixture of camping and rushing, due to the offense and defense phases.

The classes are predefined, so you can't use whatever weapons you want. They are locked to different squad types, and to the different classes within those squad types. For example, a squad leader might only have a pistol, but they also have he ability to call in an artillery strike which can make the difference between holding objectives or not. I personally think it's a good move to have weapons locked to classes, because that eliminates the possibility for everyone to just use machine guns. It allows for a good variety of weaponry on the battlefield, and gives use to the squads.

It's by no means perfect, and there are really annoying querks like not being able to shoot through barbed wire that happen at times, but overall it's highly enjoyable. Patches come out frequently, and it really feels like the developers are doing/want to do the best they can with it. I certainly recommend it, especially if you have a group of friends you can squad up with.

reviewText:
Before buying this game, ask yourself:

Do you like being shot by people you didn't or can't see?
Do you like being shot by people you thought were a stump or rock?
Do you like getting your limbs blown off by explosions?
Do you like getting shot from afar, or perhaps mowed down by a machingun?
Do you like getting disemboweled on a bayonet?

If you answered no to all those questions like a normal sane human being- TOO BAD BUY THE GAME AND PLAY IT ANYWAY! NOW GO GRAB THAT RIFLE AND GET OUT THERE!
GO GO GO! OVER THE TOP!

After some time of playing you'll be:
Killing people that can't see you!
Killing people while they mistake you for a inanimate object!
Blowing peoples limbs off with explosions!
Killing people from afar and mowing your enemies down!
Jamming bayonets through your enemies gut!

Now after following this sort of guide/review you will be a master of the game! A beast of the Western Front!

11/10 Game. Get now or be executed for treason.

reviewText: I layed down holding my rifle tightly as I watched my friends being shredded by enemy fire. We were attempting to take a trench ontop of a hill that ws very important for the battle. I had not yet been spottd for i was laying down in a patch of tall, thick grass. I was about tn feet from the east side of the trench. The trench sprawled to the west for another 100 feet or more. I saw an enemy infantryman behind a tree to my left diagonaly about 10 feet away, him being right infront of the trench. He was facing the other direction. I saw my chance and I took it. I sprinted up to the side of him and pushedd my bayonet as hard as I could Into his side. He died instantly. I then proceeded to run into the trench and crouch down. I saw an enemy about 20 feet awaying coming my way through the trenches. I then layed down and pointed my rifle at the exact possition I was going to shoot him at. I saw him come out and I fired and watched as his lifeless body hit the ground. I stood up and ran, but before I knew what was going on, it was too late. I ran passed an enemy MG and he opened fir on me and I was torn to peices and hit the floor. I Sat there watching as my allies stormed the place. I realized that not only had I sacrificed myself for my team, but also caused a distraction just long enough for my men to take the trench. thats all I thought about as a faded into the after life. Then I respawne and did it again.

reviewText:
To be short. Devs added new features in good old FPS shooter:
4 Squads, each 4 players. Each player has a role. And 4 squads in team that has a role too — spotters, close quarters, supports. Finally someone made a true frontline game. Ain't this points that we see everywhere. Something fresh!
Atmosphere is great. For a first time multiplayer game that depress you with fears and terrors of war. For real, I feel Remarque's spirit in this game. Sometimes when you run from trench to trench, you think — why I'm doing this, what is the reason, why I have to kill another people, but then you getting're you unlock...

Worthy game, especialy on sale. More stuff to come, watch xmas truce event — dat is gorgeous.
----
Update 16.01.15
Devs repolished engine, now it's Unity 5. New sound, animations, supression and shellshock features.
----
Update 27.10.15
Stability increased. Game came out from Early Access. So how it plays?

It's a son of Insurgency + Red Orchestra 2. Better then Insurgency but not so polished like RO2. U got no tanks here on the battlefield and only 32 players. Weapons are good, you feel them. Game has it's own atmosphere of trench's warfare. Frontline mode -- first you attack then you hold. Devs cut the nerve -- you really feel the insanity of war. You keep dying trying to reach trench, then you got to fall back and it's infinite. I read Remarque's book about WWI and it's really that feel.

But if you pass this period you will get E.Junger experience. You will start love that insanity. Trench's massacre, close quarters battle rage.
Also each map is different. In 1914 it's more about rifle shootings, in 1918 -- class quarters in trenches.

+ Weapons
+ Well designed historical clothes
+ Balance -- you need to teamplay
+ Frontline mode
+ Devs learn a lot about WW1
+ Speed Bolting

= Not for everyone.

- Glitch sometimes
- Only 32 players
- Bad VoIP
- No tanks, cars.


I'm looking forward that Devs will continue shape and add new features like they did in early access. Great road from more mode than game to Insurgency 2 level game.

05.12.15
Fixed review. Found that there are speed bolting like in RO2. Check it in options

reviewText:
Verdun is a very fun objective based shooter. You battle through the trenches, attacking or defending based on your teams momentum. If as an attacker you manage to push into a forward trench and hold it, then the enemy will be forced to retreat to a further back trench. While advancing or retreating you may find yourself in no man's land, where explosions and gunfire tend to tear you apart, but it's still exciting when you survive. There is a good mixture of camping and rushing, due to the offense and defense phases.

The classes are predefined, so you can't use whatever weapons you want. They are locked to different squad types, and to the different classes within those squad types. For example, a squad leader might only have a pistol, but they also have he ability to call in an artillery strike which can make the difference between holding objectives or not. I personally think it's a good move to have weapons locked to classes, because that eliminates the possibility for everyone to just use machine guns. It allows for a good variety of weaponry on the battlefield, and gives use to the squads.

It's by no means perfect, and there are really annoying querks like not being able to shoot through barbed wire that happen at times, but overall it's highly enjoyable. Patches come out frequently, and it really feels like the developers are doing/want to do the best they can with it. I certainly recommend it, especially if you have a group of friends you can squad up with.

reviewText: Verdun is a great game that hits that sweet spot between realism and annoying ease. However, if you have a group of friends who enjoys squad play, this is a great game to get.\n\nThe biggest downside to the game is the lack of player base; I would also like to see some different game modes, and I hope to see those in the future. At $22, it's a fair price. On sale, it's a steal.

reviewText:
I honestly wanted to play a bit longer before reviewing this game, but I guess they deserve it.
This game is wonderful. Simple as that. Learning curve is not as steep as you'd imagine, and the first hours are a bit frustrating but eventually you will just learn how to survive more than 0.2 seconds in a row.
It's realistic, it's cool, and most importantly it's fun. Real fun. If you love WW1 you will love this game.
Entente Powers and Central Empires are divided in squads (4) each with their own abilities and roles, and each squad is divided into roles (4), each with their own weapons and charateristics, bonuses and maluses (32 players in total may seem few, but trust me, there's a lot of action going on all the time if both armies are full). Each squads also has an NCO providing forward spawn points, artillery, gas attacks, def/atk bonuses and whatnot, depending on the squad you're in. You start with basic equipment, and you can unlock more advanced one with experience points gained on the battlefield. Teamwork is highly valued and encouraged. In fact, highly teamworking teams will be awarded with several bonuses and better armour. Balancing system is extremely clever and fitting, too. Voting system is cool as well.
Just know that many actions involve real hardcore camping (just as you'd expect, I guess...), but it's fun nonetheless.
Also expect a lot of prone blocking.
And some major FPS drop from time to time.
But it's still a wonderful game.
Only flaw I can think of is the absence of a squad chat. That woulf fit A LOT.

reviewText:
Charging an enemy trench with my stormtrooper squad; Lewis gun rifle rounds whistle  past me and hit one of my comrades and he goes down. The sounds of him choking on his own blood resound out behind me as the last three of us jump over the top of the enemy trench, landing behind the Lewis gunner who had to stop and reload. The first man in bayonets the gunner and kills him, his lifeless body falling to the dirt, groans of pain following. Shots ring out from down the trench as two brits open up with their Enfield,  my two team mates go down, blood shoots from their chests as the rounds make impact. I charge over their writhing groaning bodies and open up with my mp 18/i, closing the gap to render their rifles useless. I empty my 32 round snail drum spraying from the hip and watch the two soldiers drop. I reload and get to the top of the parapet just in time to see two french squads charging towards me to retake the trench. I take aim an fire.

10/10 would get PTSD again.

This new update completes the game. Get it now.

reviewText:
Fun bolt-action shooter that requires some patience to play and either quick reflexes or a good eye. Strongest part of the game is that it is very team-based; victory predicates on your team working together, not on kills.

Guns are fun enough to shoot and have minor variations, but as all rifles are one shot kills, the only real differences are clip size, rate of fire, and sightings. Pistols are fun but useless at range, MG's are powerful and are excellent defensive weapons that must be setup to be useful. There is no need to worry about weapons overheating, however, so they can be a bit lacking in depth.

Poison gas is a very cool element of this game and does a great job of mixing up a fight, bringing everyone into close-range shootouts and melees and blocking line of sight.

Map selection is limited, but I do believe more are planned. Their individual quality is surprisingly good considering they are mostly made up of pot-holes and trenches.

Performance wise Verdun runs OK but tends to have variable performance even on higher end systems with medium graphics settings.

Overall a solid purchase for anything under $20. $23 is acceptable, but this is a game you know will go on sale for deep discounts.

reviewText:
Verdun is an amazing game. It's a huge breath of fresh air from all the terrible historical games that follow the formula of: you are the Mary Sue American hero, that is the evil German Nazi, kill the Nazi, you've saved the world. It gives you a chance to see that war from all sides and better yet it actually has more factions that America. In fact, they don't have America at all! In terms of Entente powers you have British Tommies, Canadians (a rare sight in gaming), and two different French divisions. In terms of Central powers you have three different German divisions. It certianly gives you a wide variety of choices. At last a good game about World War 1!

Pros:
-diverse gameplay
-wide variety of faction choices
-interesting squad level system
-artillery!
-gets away from the stantard good guy/bad guy formula

Cons:
-some maps favor snipers very heavily
-French rifles are absolutely terrible but that is something that is out of the developers' control
-some odd situations where you're sitting in a shell hole or a trench and you get killed through a hill and a few meters of solid dirt and sandbags

Wishes:
-Austrio-Hungarian factions
-Anzac troops
-Vehicles and weapons for dealing with them (not sure about this one)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a player of the original Red Orchestra mod, I fell in love with Verdun almost immediately.

It is dominated by the same, slow, considered bolt-action rifle gameplay that RO-MOD was and it is glorious.

The game extremely atmospheric and the maps are excellent. Putting your gas mask on and charging with your squad into a mass of yellow gas as whistles are going off in the background and tommies yelling OVER THE TOP BOYS!" is really quite fun.

There is no game quite like it.

Worth every penny."
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a ton of potential.

This a great squad based first-person tactical shooter that punishes you again and again for the decisions you make (and don't). This game is not for the lone wolves out there. You assuredly will die by a K98 or SMLE fire and your corpse will jiggle on the barbed wire.

You will die following your buddies breaching trenches too. A stray bullet whizzes past your comrades into your heart. Your last breath is a 3rd person view of your comrades awkwardly running into the trench avenging your death!  How glorious.

You will die by artillery. You will spawn again in 20 seconds and be killed by artillery. You will be an NCO and call artillery on the enemy positions. You will not kill anyone with your artillery.

Sometimes, though, sometimes you don't die. Sometimes you get the drop on your target. Sometimes your artillery lands and nets 5 kills. Sometimes your charge following your artillery barrage means you caught the enemy by surprise and 5 types of blood wet your bayonet or trench shovel.

The game is just so much fun. Be patient, be cooperative, and press shift to hold your breath for accurate fire!

The real mastery of the game comes in how you play each class. NCOs should stay back and provide themselves as support/safe spawn to keep attacks fresh. Machine gunners should find perfect vantage points and fire down on reinforcements...

Great game.

reviewText:
This game has an amazing idea. But every patch that has come (and probably will come) will just ♥♥♥♥ it all up.
It has big performance issues, the ragdolls are terrible (and fixed, but return from time to time), there is random teleports, random glitches, everything. Name it and this game has it.

I liked the game a lot, but now it is overrun by camping idiots who do not attack in the attack phase, and later are confused why they didn't win.

The only positive thing is that it's fun when you understand its mechanics and such, but that WILL take a lot of time as it has a steep learning curve.

Overall in the current state: 4/10

EDIT:
Due to very very very good optimization, I will change my review. The game is very well playable again.

The mentality of most players is still that sitting in your trench will get you rewarded with the enemy trench, but that's part of the game.
For the game I'd say 7/10 as of now.
Most players'd still get my previous 4/10

Keep up the good work, gentlemen!

reviewText:
Fun bolt-action shooter that requires some patience to play and either quick reflexes or a good eye. Strongest part of the game is that it is very team-based; victory predicates on your team working together, not on kills.

Guns are fun enough to shoot and have minor variations, but as all rifles are one shot kills, the only real differences are clip size, rate of fire, and sightings. Pistols are fun but useless at range, MG's are powerful and are excellent defensive weapons that must be setup to be useful. There is no need to worry about weapons overheating, however, so they can be a bit lacking in depth.

Poison gas is a very cool element of this game and does a great job of mixing up a fight, bringing everyone into close-range shootouts and melees and blocking line of sight.

Map selection is limited, but I do believe more are planned. Their individual quality is surprisingly good considering they are mostly made up of pot-holes and trenches.

Performance wise Verdun runs OK but tends to have variable performance even on higher end systems with medium graphics settings.

Overall a solid purchase for anything under $20. $23 is acceptable, but this is a game you know will go on sale for deep discounts.

reviewText:
Some good points about verdun
-immersive gameplay
- wide selection of WW1 weapons and the tatics to uses them
-teamwork is something you have to do to hold or take any ground
-realistic in ways, 1 shot from a bolt action will be the end of you, being right next to a grenade will not be a good time for you
-good maps that make attacking hard but not impossible, with a good team you can do anything

now
some bad points.
-stacking, all high ranks stack on one team, this is a problem considering new players aren't even getting a chance when they're getting shot from 150m out(although this will improve your skills)
-melee, its not satisfying enough, its like you're poking them with a stick, there is no weight in the melee so you might as well be
-performance and glitches have been an issue as well, although not game breaking, just irritating

in conclusion I'd reccomend this to anyone who enjoys bolt action rifles and charges, buy this.

reviewText:
Before buying this game, ask yourself:

Do you like being shot by people you didn't or can't see?
Do you like being shot by people you thought were a stump or rock?
Do you like getting your limbs blown off by explosions?
Do you like getting shot from afar, or perhaps mowed down by a machingun?
Do you like getting disemboweled on a bayonet?

If you answered no to all those questions like a normal sane human being- TOO BAD BUY THE GAME AND PLAY IT ANYWAY! NOW GO GRAB THAT RIFLE AND GET OUT THERE!
GO GO GO! OVER THE TOP!

After some time of playing you'll be:
Killing people that can't see you!
Killing people while they mistake you for a inanimate object!
Blowing peoples limbs off with explosions!
Killing people from afar and mowing your enemies down!
Jamming bayonets through your enemies gut!

Now after following this sort of guide/review you will be a master of the game! A beast of the Western Front!

11/10 Game. Get now or be executed for treason.

reviewText:
Just your standard Canadian rifleman in the trenches of the Somme.  The German's attack had lost its momentum and, with the sound of a trumpet, they were in full retreat.  It was our turn to charge.  We formed an unorganized line at the ladders of the front-most trench, joined by a few British units and some Frenchmen.

When the whistle blows, the first soldiers scale the walls to enter the chaos of No Man's Land.   But the only place they get to is the muddy floor of the trench.   The next group climbs the ladder, only one makes it out.  The pattern continues until our Corporal gives us the order to attack.  And we do.  The four of us rush to the nearest crater amidst artillery, gunfire, and the roar of a passing flying machine.  Only two of us arrive; the Corporal and I.  And soon that too would change, as, with a faint snap, the Corporal is hit by a stray bullet.

So, with not a friend in sight, I pull out my trusty shovel and charge.  Germans bullets whiz by and smack against the dirt.  But they do nothing.  I make it into the German trench and wildly swing my entrenching tool in the general direction of the nearest Kraut.  There was a thud and a clang, and he falls dead.  But he was not alone.  His fellow Huns were quick to put me down with their handguns.  But the Jerry that I snagged was their Machine Gunner.  And with that gun unmanned, even for a second, our forces were able to make it further across the ruined fields.  The trench was ours.  And I was a Canadian martyr.

This is the kind of crazy ♥♥♥♥ that happens all the time in Verdun, and it's absolutely great.  Verdun is truly great, as cinematic as it is challenging.  If you want a quick run-and-gun, a game with little thinking and heavy competitive play, do not buy this game.  This is not Battlefield, and it is not CoD.

But if you want to experience a realistic depiction of the war, a challengingly realistic FPS, or a team-based game of strategy, Verdun is a must-buy.

reviewText:
Verdun is the greatest World War game since Medal of Honor in my opinion.
While it is simplistic in nature, its mechanics and weapons are on point.
Nothing like getting through 4 of the 5 bullets in your bolt action rifle's clip and knowing you need to reload, but also that you may not have time before another foe comes around the corner of the position you are looking at.
I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a classic shooter and people who have squad goals.

Today I sat in the fetal position in the middle of a dirty trench; rocking back and forth and crying while listening to my comrades scream in pain as they lay dying in a hole or somewhere else amidst no man's land.

reviewText:
One of my few serious reviews.

Pros:

WW1, very few people do this. They did it right

Good graphics, I like all the graphics they are great and very well textured and thought out. I like that a lot.

Player to map size is great, although I do want one more squad per map, I feel some maps such as Pircade are a little under populated and not very fun. One more squad would fix that.

Wide range of map choices. From hills to forrest, to a fortress. I like that, I like that a lot.

Great gunplay, I like how the guns feel and look. They fire accuratley if you hold down shift while looking down. Also when aiming down sight due to your player breathing the scope and gun will move so make sure to shift when aiming down sights when you are about to fire, makes it a lot easier.

NO DLCS, yes this is a PLUS. I am sick of paying for a DLC, I hate them. Excluding EU4 dlcs. But Verdun offers so much when it comes to the one time buy. No pay to win, all skill based which is grea too. I am very glad they do not have a DLC. If they do add a DLC I would hope they add the Eastern front as a DLC for 20 dollars I think is a fair price. New maps, guns and factions for that is what I would 100% buy.

The gore update is great, I love losing my leg, arm or whatever to a bomb, bullet or nade. I like this a lot.

Great sounds, very nice

Neutral

I am neutral to the player size, as I said one more squad would be a lot better.

The maps although good are a bit lacking in some areas but still great. Wish they were more trench like, where you can pier over the side without exposing half your body.

Selection of joining a match is good, which they added how much time is left. I hate joining my favorite map and in 30s the round ends, wish they added a timer in the selection menu.

Filtering out certain squads. I know you can choose your own however it would be a nice touch to add an ability to filter out certain squads such as Canadians, U.S Marines, etc.

Cons:

Communication is the worst I have ever seen. No voice, or at least voice that is useful. They need to add localized voice chat, squad chat and squad leader chat to allow squad leads to talk to each other as well as squad members to talk to each other and localized proxy chat. No one reads chat, no one. It takes too long to type in combat and over all the worst I've seen in a game that requires fast paced action. An example of just 30 minutes ago I was in a match in the fort and a German sat in a corner and fired at everyone who ran by. I saw him. However almost everyone went right by him every time. I was talking in team chat and NO ONE payed attention to it. Also those goes for ALL players pay attention to chat please.

No campgain however this is a multiplayer game that is expected but if they did add a DLC a campaign would be nice as either German, Americans, French or British would be a great 20 dollar addon that I would buy easily.

No rewarding upgrades, I use mostly stock guns because they are so good so for players like me who have a good amount of time in no rewarding guns in higher up levels are any good. Excluding MG and Greandier.

Can be a bit glitchy.

My other complaint about gore is that you cannot shoot a dead body and it splat blood, I wish you could do that.

Overall

Yes this is a good game, I would recommend buying it for 25 it is worth it, at FULL price. I got this for cheap on sale so I was very lucky and it has TON of replay ability. The devs constanly update it adding a ton of things. Gore is great. I would rate this 8/10. Worth a buy? Yes.

reviewText: First thing's first, Verdun doesn't play like other FPS games. Don't play it expecting another Call of Duty or Counterstrike. It is brutal and unforgiving as a WW1 game should be and that's exactly why I like it. You will die, many times. Sometimes you will die being caught on barbed wire, sometimes from a sniper or machinegun shot that you never saw fired, sometimes from relentless artillery barrages. I really enjoy it as it just feels _right_ in it's WW1 setting. It's never long till you respawn and join the next wave though. Try Verdun for a different, historical FPS experience.\n\nI will say there seem to be some issues surrounding hit detection and some 'teleporting' where you suddenly bounce into the air, but they are few and far between. I look forward to future updates to the game!

reviewText:
A very intense multiplayer game based on the battle of Verdun which lasted for quite some time.

In Christmas Time, the game actually replicates what the soldiers did which was come out to No Man's Land and play soccer with one another (Allies and Axis) and trade gifts.

The game itself is very deep with realistic ballistics of the guns. Also the soldiers (Both Axis and Entente) look authentic. The experience system makes you come back for more.

The gameplay itself is straightforward as both teams attempt to takeover the other. The Entente (Allies) go against the Central (Axis) and both teams attack one another until one team has enough momentum to full on crush the other team. However, they can lose that momentum thus they become the hunted!

If I had one complaint, it would be that sometimes, there are not enough people playing!

Overall, I think everyone who has played Red Orchestra before will love this game and for those who are new to this type of shooter, I think you guys will enjoy it!

reviewText:
Verdun Revisited
My initial review was pretty sparse on details, plus the game has been updated and added to so much since that I decided to re-review.

Verdun is a realistic World War I multi-player first-person shooter trench-warfare simulator (Whew!). You either play as Entente Powers (French, English, Canadian, Belgian, and American) or as Central Powers (German).

As of this review, there are four game modes:

1) Rifle Deathmatch: Free for all, rifles only, no teams. New players start here, as all weapons except for one rifle are locked at the beginning of your Verdun career. You have to earn career points to unlock weapons, and you earn career points by doing well in matches.

2) Attrition Full-Arsenal Team Deathmatch: Play on a team as either the Entente or Central powers. Choose a primary & secondary weapon from a variety of authentic weapons used at the Western Front. It's important to note that these weapons are locked to new players. Again, you use career points to unlock weapons.

3) Squad Defence Co-operative Wave defence: Basically a practice mode for Frontlines. Play in a squad of one to four players against endless waves of AI bots. You can still gain XP, medals, and unlock weapons and achievements in this mode.

4) Frontlines Squad Based Trench Warfare: The most complex game mode. I recommend getting experienced in all other modes before even attempting this one. Play in a squad of up to four players as either the Entente or Central powers against other squads. Capture trenchlines and defend trechlines. Teamwork and communication are very important when playing Frontlines.

PROS:
-Realistic: One shot, one kill with rifles. Bullet drop at long ranges. You have to lead moving targets, expecially at distance. There are suppression/shellshock effects (vision and hearing partially goes out, and you can hear your heart pounding).

-Authentic WWI Weapons: Gas, trench melee weapons, flame throwers, artillery barrages, and of course machine guns to name a few.

-Authentic WWI Battlefield Maps: There are nine total maps at the time of this review: Vauquois (only available in Rifle DM and Attrition), Vosges, Douaumont, Argonne, Champagne (Night), Aisne, Picardie, Artois, and Flanders.

-Gore Mode: A gore option was added in the last major update (which is off by default). Burnt bodies, limbs blown off, caved-in heads, lotsa blood, etc.

-Immersive Sound: Great sound effects, making the game all the more immersive. Sometimes when a player is killed, he'll lay there screaming and writhing in agony for what seems like minutes. Quite demoralizing! (Gore mode must be on).

-Great Community: Compared to other multi-player games I've played, Verdun has a really good community. Most experienced players are friendly and will offer advice to new players if asked.

-Developers Are Very Active: Devs are constantly improving, tweaking, adding to, etc.

-The Only WWI FPS Currently: Currently" because I just found out that Battlefield 1 is set in WWI
date: and will be coming out soon. I don't count NecroVision because
hoursPlayed: if you've played it or even seen the store page
voteText:
you'd understand.

CONS:
-No Friendly Fire: For such an otherwise realistic game
helpfulPercent: this is something that really needs to be added.\n\n-Default Keyboard/Mouse Layout: You'll save yourself a lot of aggravation if you modify your keyboard/mouse layout for at least melee before playing. Also
votesHelpful: you may want to change the crouch and prone keys.\n\n-Difficult For New Players: There isn't an in-game tutorial
votesTotal: but there are helpful guides and gameplay videos
votesFunny: as well as a spectator mode in-game.\n\n-Glitches/Bugs: There are definitely some issues
commentsCount: rarely something happens that breaks a match. I have had to exit and restart the game a few times due to glitches though.\n\n-Multi-Player Only: This game is really built for multi-player. If the devs did make a single-player campaign
column16: it would be probably be similar to Red Orchestra 2 single-player - separate from the multi-player game
column17: and not much fun.\n\n-Small Community: Weekends are the best times to play on the US server. Any other time
column18:
& all you'll be able to play is Frontlines and Squad Defence.

BOTTOM LINE:
I highly recommend Verdun. It's a frustrating learning experience at first
column19: but stick with it. When you get good at this game
column20:
it's a lot of fun! See you in the trenches!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is FANTASTIC. That's not an understatement! It's a squad-based FPS that takes place in the trenches, with many dynamic maps. Not as many maps as I'd like, but i know that they will come out with more maps soon! There are 4 different classes per squad-type. First one is Corporal (at least that's what it is in English!), second one is along the lines of a sniper, third is a Heavy-Gunner (machine gun) and fourth is the dude with the grenades! BOOM! As of now, you can choose to play as Canada, Great Britain, France, and Germany. The countries each have their own weapons and specialties. The devs never cease to amaze me!

Hope this review helped,
Mega

reviewText:
Played only 22 hours so far. Game looks good, feels good and has a very good replayability for the price.
There are no vehicles in game - it is heavily focused on trench warfare and infantry combat.
Maps are rather small and you will not have problem getting into fight.
Most weapons are bolt-action, so your reaction and ability to aim matter much more.
The teams are divided into squads - you level them up during your session and unlock bonuses (and it's much more fun playing with your friends).
There are flaws and bugs, but I never met any that can force me out of game.
I recommend you to check the game out.

reviewText:
All I had was a shovel, I had thrown all of my granades, but I was stuck alone in the enemies' trench.
While trying to find my comrades, I happened upon almost half a dozen enemies.
Something in me sparked, I'm not sure what, but I charged, brutally smashing the first 2 men's heads.
The others turned to see me bash another one of their comrades' faces.
They shot, most likely before aiming, and they missed me by a margin.
I could only see black and white while I screamed something only a savage could.
I stuck my spade into the last few enemies.
When I had finally awoke from my barbaric instincts, I sat there, speechless, wondering what I had just done.
All I could hear was one of the men screaming, and another gurgling as he choked on his own blood.
I was still paralyzed when I came to the realization of what I had just done, Wha-...AHHHHHH!" I screamed aloud

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is frustrating and wonderful. It is not COD, and it shouldn't be. Every battle begins variously with charging at the enemy and definitely getting gunned down or gunning down the enemy who is charging at you in a near hopeless, but sometimes fruitful attempt to get into the ruddy trench you are in. That's just the experience of the game, but there is far more.

Want to shoot a machine gun? You'll have to work for it. No-one starts this game with machineguns or SMGs, they either end up with a pistol and a bundle of grenades or with one of the bolt-action rifles each of the various entente and central powers sent their boys out with. You'll ask questions like: Why the hell did the French design a rifle with only three rounds that could not be reloaded in between? Why? Then you'll realize the beauty of the Lee Enfield and the utilitarian vigor of the G98. The choice of weapon is decided based on which power your squad is with, the role in the quad you get, and how well you have fought in that role to garner various specializations. It's a nice system, and I have enjoyed the fun of trying to level up every specialty. It's a good way of promoting experiementation which I appreciate.

What about Beta?

This game has some obvious bugs which can screw up the sky and ground, but for the most part, the game still needs development in it's matchmaking capabilities. Too often, players are sent into battles without enough other players, and the game doesn't seem to send new players where they are needed, because you stick with your squad into the net battle. That design has its pros, but the con is that empty games, while uncommon, occur too frequently for a good release.

Oftentimes, the servers time out and you get dropped from a game, or your squad doesn't get a position in a battle, and you therefore have to retry making your squad.

The friend function in the game is skeletal. The developers obviously have the buttons there to make everything else functional, but there is no easy way of connecting players with their steam accounts and getting steam friends into games can sometimes be difficult. There are great examples of how to make this system function, and I think the developers will do it justice.

The community on the game has been largely understanding of the beta status, as well, and in in-game chat, I've seen the regular amount of trolling and criticism, but it seems that most of the players are pretty into the game with all its drawbacks, and would rather have a good game and some fun, than ruin the experience for anyone else.

Verdun is a great game. There are some problems, but it has the makings to be the first truly successful game set in the Great War. If you have a love for realism, and can deal with being shot repeatedly, you should get it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this is probably the best WW1 game to have been made (even though that list is VERY small).

The weapons are very realistic, and the gun play is second to none. The back-and-forth pushing and retreating to and from the trenches across No Mans Land is just as it was. It really gives a sense of the type of warfare conducted 100 years ago.

Proper WW1 trench warfare with accurate weapons including chlorine gas attacks, various pushing and retreating cycles, and if you get stuck in the barbed wire, you either die from being stuck and bleeding or get shot. It's only in Beta but it's pretty well done. Think of it like Battlefield, you join as 4 player squads within the server, and have 4x squads on each team versing each other.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought I was done with FPS games. I'd given up thinking that anyone could make the formula fun again. I'd asumed that any online multiplayer FPS would be populated entirely by jerks intent on making your gaming experience miserable.

Verdun proved me wrong. So very, very wrong.

Verdun is a seriously brilliant team-based FPS. The game mechanic of opposing forces attacking and counter attacking; driving each other out of a position and having to hold it is terrific. It really makes you think of your role in the team and not just racking up your kill count.

Also, if like me you're a history buff; the developers have spent a lot of time getting the setting, uniforms and weapons to feel authentic; but they've still managed to balance the game" aspects excellently.

As for your online gaming experience  - the players are

reviewText:
Verdun is, as it stands, an fun game version of combat on the Western Front of the First World War. It naturally takes historical liberties and these make it not simply a bland historical simulator. The 'frontlines' game type and the maps it is played on is balanced enough that you get these great tug of war scenarios, so every victory really feels like a success. The maps are surprisingly diverse considering the setting, though for being named 'Verdun' there aren't as many sprawling forts as you'd expect.

There is room for improvement in the squad system (which is far from intuitive) and the way the game deals with team balance.

While I play and enjoy a range of games set in historical and current day conflicts, this of all I felt the most uncomfortable about, which is odd. I guess WWI has a particular place in, at least Australia's, cultural psyche.

Overall it is a fun game and I would recommend it.

Early Access Review

Here is my review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought I was done with FPS games. I'd given up thinking that anyone could make the formula fun again. I'd asumed that any online multiplayer FPS would be populated entirely by jerks intent on making your gaming experience miserable.

Verdun proved me wrong. So very, very wrong.

Verdun is a seriously brilliant team-based FPS. The game mechanic of opposing forces attacking and counter attacking; driving each other out of a position and having to hold it is terrific. It really makes you think of your role in the team and not just racking up your kill count.

Also, if like me you're a history buff; the developers have spent a lot of time getting the setting, uniforms and weapons to feel authentic; but they've still managed to balance the game" aspects excellently.

As for your online gaming experience  - the players are
recommended: a friendly lot. They won't give you a second chance if you mess up (bang!)
hoursPlayed: but they're not going to grief you or otherwise make your experience unpleasant.\n\nOne note for new players - there's a very steep learning curve. You will die A LOT. You usually won't know where that fatal shot came from
voteText: either. That can be frustrating. Stick with it. The game rewards ongoing play.\n\nI can't recommend this game highly enough. Buy it

reviewText:
Simple match mechanics, a simple squad support system, a nice (but small-ish) variety of maps and a great community make this a game worth picking up. It's still in beta, so there are still a few kinks (my issues have ONLY been with the menus, no in-match problems yet @ roughly 6 hours of play). Overall, it doesn't FEEL like a beta, at least not like the ones I've played.

The only thing that is a bit dissapointing is the lack of variety in weaponry. There are 2-3 bolt rifles per side, with unlockable scopes, bayonets and reinforced butts (hehe) depending on which class you play. Some classes like officers can have pistols and binoculars to call in recon or gas/mortar strikes, while flankers can equip rifles or pistols, and are equipped with devastating grenades. There is an LMG class for each side, the German class can only fire while deployed, while the French and British LMG's can be fired while on the move. It would be nice to have some sort of shotgun class (maybe the grenadiers?), but the developers have covered the basic necessities and provided some variety.

Overall, I am highly impressed with this very polished beta, and would recommend it to any of my friends.

EDIT (10/31/15, 210 hrs)
It's a few months after the official release, and this game just keeps getting better and better. The devs are putting out 2-3 updates a month, mostly graphical updates and bug fixes. They've announced a ton of FREE upcoming DLC, and post weekly updates to the community and social media that detail progress being made, and discuss where the future updates are headed.

The player community itself is the best I've ever experienced. Players are (with very few exceptions) helpful, friendly and communicate well. Squad voice chat is useful, and more and more players are using mics and taking advantage of this. Every so often, you'll run across a developer playing in-game and answering questions.

Gameplay has improved, squad mechanics have been smoothed, and a team deathmatch (no trench captures, just killing) has been added. Squad roles and classes ahve been revamped, new weapons have been added: knives, shovels, clubs, and more. With more weapons (BAR, 1911, Springfield, shotgun and a German flamethrower) and new squads (Americans, Belgians) coming soon, this game comtinues to hold my interest.

I'd still highly recommend this game for anyone who loves a good shooter, especially historical ones.

reviewText:
Awesome game. Very interesting mechanics. You work in a 4 man squad, with each man having a different role. From the pistol-brandishing officer, to the trench club wielding Raider, you should be able to find a loudout that fits your playstyle.
A couple of things to be noted though:
The game is going for realism, which means 1 rifle bullet kills you, so expect to die a lot when you get started (you can survive a couple pistol bullets).
THE GAS WILL KILL YOU
SO WILL BARBED WIRE
So be smart; gas mask-up and be careful around the wire.
The graphics are good, and the game is extremely fun.
